ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: combined virtual/occasional in-person seminar
Virtual seminar, sometimes in person
Virtual seminar and sometimes in-person discussion
This class consisted mostly of virtual seminar style discussions but we were able to meet in person a few times, while abiding by all covid-19 guidelines and rules.
Sometimes we went to her house.
We sometimes met in person, which was nice.

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to really get what I want from a text and use its techniques for my ownto "selfishly read" as Professor Shirkhani noted.

I learned so much from this class - it is hard to put into words. I learned to be a better writer (a more honest, real, relatable writer), but also a better critical thinker and reader. More than that, this class inspired me to be a more honest and genuine person both through my writing and through conversations with peers.
I learned how to analyze techniques that writers use in writing the modern essay. I then learned how to apply these techniques to my own personal writing.
How to write a non-fictional essay, and how to close-read texts and improve your own writing in the process.
I learned a lot about what modern writing means and how to approach it - beginning with at the sentence level.

I learned how to read and write at a much more technical level. This class focused on non-fiction narrative style writing with five different categories of focus: personal experience, place, person, cultural critique, and satire. For each unit we looked at different essays and studied the different techniques that authors used. In doing this we learned how to write in a way that uses what we experience as a reader to convey and convince our readers of what we want to say in our writing.

How to read at a higher level. 
How to be more nuanced in your writing and lead the reader without forcing an idea on them. 
How to show not tell. 
How to edit yours and your peers writing.
I learned how to think critically about texts and how to analyze them from a literature/structural perspective.
I learned how to analyze different works of literature in order to replicate the techniques in my own work.
I learned to think about writing English essays in a better way.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strength: amazing instructor, fun readings
Weakness: readings can be pretty short one day, then super-duper long the next (cough cough David Foster Wallace). perhaps more consistency in length of reading homework.

I cannot think of any weaknesses of this course. It was simply amazing - definitely the best course I have taken so far at Yale. The topics are all engaging and relevant. The discussions are thought-provoking and there is real improvement in student writing (which I saw in both myself and my classmates).

Strengths: good reading selection, manageable workload, good feedback given on essays, GREAT professor who made class engaging

Weaknesses: some more direction could've been giving when writing the essays (i.e. having a general outline of techniques used in the sample essays to then apply to our own writing)

Strengths: Prof Shirkhani is a godsend. She is engaging, insightful, warm, compassionate and understanding, and she will do everything to make sure you are doing your best in her class. Her feedback on draft essays were tremendously helpful, and drastically improved the loose ends in my writing. The readings (sample essays) are also artfully chosen, covering a wide spectrum of genres and styles of personal narratives, and most were fun to read.
Weaknesses: There is always a draft or final essay due soon, which is somewhat stressful, especially if you dont know where to start. I guess the stress contributes to your writing in some form though.

Professor Shirkhani was amazing at teaching different writing techniques and tools through the sample essays we were given to read. I loved the essays that she chose for us to read and loved how we were able to discuss and ask questions about the essays. I also really enjoyed the workshops, both having my essay workshopped and being able to workshop the essays of my peers. I think both the structure and format of the class was awesome.

Strengths: Professor Shirkhani. She provided a lot of insightful comments on the readings and your own writing. She would always see more in your writing than you did, and would suggest ideas to improve it. The reading list was amazing. 

Weaknesses: Readings were difficult and required a lot of time, but hey, what do you expect?
A strength of this course was the amount of feedback I got for each piece of writing I turned in for the course. A weakness was the amount of reading required outside of class time.

It was an interesting way to think about writing essays, and taught me a lot about writing, however I feel like it could have focused more on the technical aspects of writing an essay, rather than the theoretical.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think that the virtual seminar experience was sort of hard to get used to at first, but it takes time.

This course was super great, despite the strange COVID-19 situation. The seminar style made it much easier to have authentic conversations with classmates. The professor and seminar style also allowed us to foster a real sense of community and friendship among ourselves. I honestly met one of my best friends through this course - through Zoom private messaging! This was only possible because of the sense of community built into our discussions.

I really appreciated how the professor dropped one essay. In other words, in a regular school year, 5 essays would have to be written; this year, you could choose not to write one. This lesser workload considered the external difficulties students already experience because of the pandemic.
I think discussions went very well over zoom, but maybe incorporating the use of the chat and emphasizing that a bit more could help students who may be a little hesitant to participate in class.

This was my favorite class, and I really enjoyed hearing Shirkhani's thoughts on the readings. I also really enjoyed workshopping day. Sometimes, though, engagement from the students was low. I would say a written response of a question to kickstart conversations might have been helpful.
Google Docs worked well.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! Kim is a phenomenal instructor, and I've told my friends to register for next spring's 2021 ENGL 120 class with Kim. I also really felt the class community even though everything was online.

YES, I would tell any student to please take this course if you have the opportunity to do so. It will push you to be a better writer and a better thinker, to examine real controversial issues, and to examine yourself as both a writer and a person.

If you're looking for a writing credit, I would highly recommend this course. Because all the essays are personal, it made the writing process very fun and the class engaging. The readings are very manageable!

If you enjoy reading non-fictional pieces (like what you might find in The New Yorker), the readings wont feel like much work. If you want to become better at writing non-fictional essays, and writing in general, this course is for you. If Professor Shirkhani is teaching this, take it with her!
If a student wishes to improve their writing and read great modern essays, this class will help them achieve that.
Absolutely. Even as a stem kid, Ive had a lot of fun reading the material and writing the essays.
Yes, I definitely see improvement in myself as a writer and learned so much about writing. Probably my favorite class this semester!
Yes, for sure. Especially with Professor Shirkhani. She provides the best comments on your writing, truly unparalleled.
No,  I would not recommend this course to another student because of the workload of this course.
Yes, I would, it's a good way to learn how to write.
